description.narrative: Effective institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place to enhance the implementation of disaster and climate risk management measures at national and sub-national levels

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: The First Biennial Update Report (FBUR) and Fourth National Communication (4NC) of the Republic of Tajikistan under the UNFCCC Convention in accordance with its commitments as a non-Annex 1 Party (as mandated by Article 4 and 12 of this Convention) and COP 17 decisions, are prepared and submitted.

comment.narrative: The Third National Communication (3NC) of the Republic of Tajikistan under the UNFCCC Convention has been prepared and submitted to the UNFCCC in accordance with its commitments as a non-Annex 1 Party (as mandated by Article 4 and 12 of this Convention) and COP 17 decisions. The system of GHG reporting in Tajikistan is non-existent.

1. Timely completion of project activities and achievement of the expected results of the project in various directions by observing the deadlines for completing each section of the project, ensuring the implementation of activities in accordance with the Project Document. Preparation of the final version of the Fourth National Communication. 2. Preparation and submission of the necessary documents to the Government for the implementation of the national Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system. 3. Forecasting greenhouse gas emissions in key sectors and assessing the impact of climate change policies and measures. To conduct training for local experts on the basics of forecasting emissions.

1. During the 2020, due to the pandemic COVID-19, project activity decreased and there was a risk of not completion of the project up to the end date. In this regard the project was extended up to 12 June 2021. Nevertheless, most of the work including key objectives and results were carried out. Collected and analyzed data on climatic conditions and socio-economic characteristics of the country over the past 10 years, related to the problems of climate change. Particular attention is paid to data on sectors of the economy that are considered sources of greenhouse gas emissions. In addition, information was provided on health care, as well as on the latest developments regarding the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the countrys economy. Data collection was carried out and the volumes of GHG emissions in key sectors of the economy for 2004-2016 were estimated. In addition, calculations of GHG emissions by precursors for all sectors for 2004–2016 were performed. Information was prepared on key sources of GHG emissions, by types of gases and emissions of precursors. The final report on the inventory of GHG emissions for 2004-2016 has been prepared, which will be included in the 4NC. according to the results of observations due to the increase in air temperature in the Zeravshan river basin for 1940-2020. by 0.11оС / 10 years and 3.1-3.4оС by 2050, as well as an increase in atmospheric precipitation by 2050 by 21-24%, the volume of runoff will increase from 29% to 39%. According to forecast data, by 2050 the glaciated area in the Zeravshan river basin will decrease to 50%. An increase in temperature in the Vakhsh river basin by 2050 is expected by 0.4 - 0.7 ° C, an increase in the amount of atmospheric precipitation by 2050 will be 7-9%. By 2050, the decrease in the flow of the Vakhsh River will be 7%. In the Pyanj river basin, by 2050, the temperature is expected to increase by 0.31-0.54 ° C and the increase in precipitation by 0.9%. It is expected that the Gunt River runoff will decrease by 3-4% by 2050 and the Vanj River runoff will increase by 5-7% by 2050. The volume of glaciers in the basins of the Vakhsh and Pyanj rivers will decrease by 55-56% and 79-80%, respectively, by 2050, while the glaciated areas will decrease by 48% and 73%, respectively. 2. MRV consultants consulted on Skype with members of the Working Group, including representatives of the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources, Industry and New Technologies, Agriculture, Transport, the Statistics Agency, the Forestry Agency, the Agency for Land Reclamation and Irrigation, State Unitary Enterprise “Zhilishno-Kommunalnoe economy ”and the Academy of Sciences. During the consultations, the sides discussed issues of relations between the above ministries and departments on the creation of the MRV system. Based on the roles and responsibilities of each ministry and organization, developing a national MRV system for inventorying greenhouse gas emissions will provide government officials, investors and other stakeholders with up-to-date and reliable information. The consultants have developed a draft Program on the national MRV system, which will be submitted to the Committee on Environmental Protection after revising the corrections. 3. The forecast of greenhouse gas emissions in Tajikistan until 2030 has been completed. A tool for forecasting has been developed. The tool estimates three different scenarios or emission pathways. The three different scenarios that have been estimated in the tool are the Without Measures (WoM) scenario, the With Existing Measures (WeM) scenario, and the With Additional Measures (WaM) scenario. A manual has been developed for independent mastering of the forecasting tool. This manual describes how to use the tool for estimating the greenhouse gas (GHG) emission projections of Tajikistan until 2030. This manual has been produced alongside a set of recorded tutorials to provide a better understanding of how to perform the estimations and how to use the tool. The recorded tutorials are mentioned in this manual when needed, to show examples or to deal with more complex issues.

1. Data collection and information using official statistics and interdepartmental documentation. Complete and update the available materials until 2018 on national conditions. 2. Preparation FBUR for 2018 and submit to UNFCCC. Calculation of GHG emissions for 2015-2016 and improving the reliability of the results of GHG emissions. 3. Based on the vulnerability assessment and adaptation, the calculation of the possible costs of long-term adaptation for the industrial, agriculture and water sector under the normal development scenario. 4. Preparation of detailed comprehensive recommendations for creating, developing and maintaining a national MRV system. 5. Based on the mitigation assessment, the calculation of the financial resources required to implement the strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions 6. Conducting a study to assess technology needs, as well as drawing up a list of the most effective technological solutions for the energy and the agricultural sector.

1. Data collection was carried out using official statistical materials and interdepartmental documentation. Existing data for the national conditions has been added and updated up to 2018. The relationships between national development strategies, sectoral and climate change policies were analyzed, which were updated on the basis of socio-economic indicators until 2018. 2. The first biennial report (FBUR) on the inventory of greenhouse gases was approved by the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan and submitted on the website of the UN Framework Convention (https://unfccc.int/BURs) on July 18, 2019. Greenhouse gas emissions for 2015 and 2016 were calculated on the basis of statistical data for sectors energy, industry, agriculture, forestry and land use, waste. 3. In the context of the effects of climate change, an assessment was made of the impacts on the land use and forestry sectors, as well as on human health and the environment. Based on the impact and adaptation assessment, a cost-benefit analysis was carried out to calculate the potential costs of long-term adaptation in the agricultural sector under the normal development scenario. 4. A letter was sent to the Government to create a working group, which should regularly collect the necessary information, register greenhouse gases and implement an internal monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system. All key ministries introduced their representatives to create a working group. A seminar was held with the participation of members of the working group from key ministries on August 26, 2019 at the Atlas Hotel (32-34 Nisor Muhammad) on the topic “Assessing Tajikistan’s Readiness to Implement the MRV System”. On the seminar was discussed the data collection process for analyzing climate change in key sectors and the specifics of implementing the MRV system. 5. Based on the climate change mitigation assessment, the necessary financial resources were compiled to implement the strategy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and a list of necessary measures was prepared. 6. A study was conducted to assess technological requirements, as well as to compile a list of the most technologically advanced requirements for the energy and agricultural sectors.

- Completed Chapter on National GHG Inventory for FNС, period 2010-2016 - In-depth vulnerability assessment of key socio-economic sectors (energy, agriculture, transport) and natural environment to climate impacts conducted. A study integrating response measures in the context of Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) and Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) conducted. - Completed Chapter on Mitigation and Policy Measures for the Fourth National Communication on Climate Change. - Completed a part of Chapter on constraints and gaps, finance, technology and capacity needs. -

To generate the outcomes and outputs for this particular project component, the project assured the following processes: - Several multilateral and bilateral consultations (online/in-room) with key national ministries and departments for the GHG emission forecast exercise/stocktaking analysis conducted. - A series of round tables (online/in-room) with the involvement of the national and international agencies, conducting the climate-related projects, to discuss and agree on priority actions and interventions already contributed to the GHG emission reduction, or would having this contribution in the future. - A training of the local experts and specialists, engaged in energy (hydropower), transport, agriculture and industry sectors, delivered to capacitate them on the GHG emission current trends and forecast as well as on potential measures their agencies might undertake to minimize the climate change impact. All the named above processes considered the INDC targets and good practices in organizing the scheme of flow processes (data collection and verification) of other countries. To validate the outcomes and outputs of this project component, the project assured the following: - Interim meetings with key national ministries and departments to introduce key findings of the assessment, forecast of GHG emission trends and a list of potential mitigation measures/actions, conducted to discuss and agree on the project outcome’s results. - The national workshop with participation of national and international stakeholders, to refine the outcome, organized; as a result, key findings of this project outcome were reflected in the FBUR and used in the updated NDC (2021). - The project team continued the practice of training local specialists on GHG Inventory, V/A and Mitigation and Policy Measures (forecasting of future GHG emissions). More junior experts were involved to the process of collecting data, desk-review and analysis. It is expected that the built-in potential of these young specialists will be further used in other climate-related interventions and activities at the national level, as well as will be contributed to the subsequent BTR and NCs preparatory process. - One of the outstanding achievements in institutional capacity building was the establishment of the Intersectoral Working Group (IWG) on MRV. Given the complexity of the topic and processes, a series of meetings and discussions with key national partners on transparency and accountability of climate actions at the domestic level, was held. This to some extent helped the members of the IWG to understand the requirements and UNFCCC decisions on transitioning to ETF and obligations of the Republic of Tajikistan. However, regular awareness raising exercises and face-to-face meetings need to be conducted in the future to maintain the agenda of the IWG and built on their functions and experience to make the domestic transparency system more sustainable.
